newsitem.title: USA: No violations of new no-fly zone in Iraq - Pentagon.
newsitem.headline: No violations of new no-fly zone in Iraq - Pentagon.

text.p: The Pentagon said on Wednesday that the United States and its allies had begun patrolling an expanded no-fly zone in southern Iraq and there had been no violations so far by Iraqi aircraft.

U.S. Air Force Gen. Joseph Ralston, deputy chairman of the military Joint Chiefs of Staff, also denied a report in an Iraqi government newspaper that Iraq had shot down a "hostile pilotless plane" over its southern province of Missan. "We have no evidence that that is true," he told reporters.

Ralston told a briefing for reporters at the Pentagon that U.S., British and French aircraft began patrolling the new no-fly zone in southern Iraq in an operation called "Southern Watch" at noon local time (0800 GMT).

"So far in operation 'Southern Watch' the enforcement of no-fly zone this morning, we noted no violations," Ralston said. "And as a matter of fact prior to the enforcement of the no-fly zone we noticed the departure of some aircraft from the airfields."

The United States on Tuesday announced an expansion of the no-fly zone in southern Iraq from the 32nd parallel to the 33rd parallel just south of Baghdad, as part of its retaliation for Iraqi attacks on Kurds in northern Iraq.

The Pentagon denial of the downing of an aircraft followed a report in the Iraqi government al-Jumhouriya newspaper that Iraqi anti-aircraft gunners shot down a "hostile pilotless plane" over its southern province of Missan. The report was not repeated by the official Iraqi News Agency (INA) and it was not confirmed by the Iraqi General Command.
